description: Protection services to Internal Displaced People (IDP) and host communities in Sheikh Daher Community Center – Lattakia
sourceObjects_Location.name: Syrian Arab Republic
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Syrian Arab Republic Humanitarian Fund
sourceObjects_Plan.name: Syria Humanitarian Response Plan 2016
sourceObjects_Emergency.name: Syrian Arab Republic - Civil Unrest (from 2012)
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Early Recovery
destinationObjects_Organization.name: ONG Rescate International
destinationObjects_Location.name: Syrian Arab Republic
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Early Recovery and Livelihoods
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Syria Humanitarian Response Plan 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Livelihoods project, including center rehabilitation, equipment for vocational training, women empowerment, with focus on adolescents and child protection – As-Sweida Center city– supporting conflict affected IDPs and host community through Community Based Activities. (Damascus Hub)
destinationObjects_Emergency.name: Syrian Arab Republic - Civil Unrest (from 2012)
project_text:
Livelihoods project, including center rehabilitation, equipment for vocational training, women empowerment, with focus on adolescents and child protection – As-Sweida Center city– supporting conflict affected IDPs and host community through Community Based Activities. (Damascus Hub) The objective of the intervention is to contribute to the resilience building of affected people and communities so as to overcome the crisis’ negative consequences and maintain a decent standard of living. The action will contribute to address the needs of IDPs population and host communities, by providing psychosocial support, vocationals training for livelihood opportunities, education activities “No Lost Generation”, and GBV and CP awareness in As-Sweida Lighthouse Community Center. 
Monitoring and Evaluation
ONG Rescate has developed a comprehensive monitoring and evaluation system in place to ensure that best practices, lessons learned, and project development are incorporated into the entire project life cycle. the progress is measured: Attendance sheets - Distribution Lists - Focus Group Discussions - Pre and Post training questionnaires - Direct beneficiary feedback - Photo Documentation - Post Distribution Monitoring assessments - Field reports - Quarterly, Interim, and Final reports (narrative and financial).

The intervention will meet the demand of the three Early Recovery & Livelihood objectives:
  Objective 1: Improve safe access to basic and social essential services and infrastructure for affected people and institutions relates to SO3
  Objective 2: Restore disrupted livelihoods for strengthened social protection and positive coping mechanisms of affected people and vulnerable groups relates to SO3
  Objective 3: Promote social cohesion and local participation for more resilient communities relates to SO2

(Damascus Hub) The objective of the intervention is to contribute to the resilience building of affected people and communities so as to overcome the crisis’ negative consequences and maintain a decent standard of living. description: Food Security assistance to meet basic needs of crisis effected population of middle shabelle.
sourceObjects_Location.name: Somalia
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Somalia Humanitarian Fund
sourceObjects_Plan.name: Somalia 2017
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Early Recovery
destinationObjects_Organization.name: Women and Children Child Care Organization
destinationObjects_Location.name: Somalia
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Somalia 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Livelihood support for emergency assistance and resilience building for the most vulnerable communities in crisis and emergency in south central somalia
project_text:
Livelihood support for emergency assistance and resilience building for the most vulnerable communities in crisis and emergency in south central somalia Objective 1: To provide immediate household access to food and increase purchasing power to the most vulnerable populations in emergency throughout the year and to people in crisis during the livelihood lean season by providing monthly food vouchers and unconditional cash relief/transfers

Objective 2: To restore community productive assets through provision of livelihoods inputs and develop alternative livelihood strategies for vulnerable population, realized via provision of farm inputs, vocational training, temporary job creation and daily stipends for maintainers of productive assets.

Objective 3: To Improve food access to school going children in vulnerable communities by providing them with daily meals to prevent further food insecurity and malnutrition
all_text:

Objective 2: To restore community productive assets through provision of livelihoods inputs and develop alternative livelihood strategies for vulnerable population, realized via provision of farm inputs, vocational training, temporary job creation and daily stipends for maintainers of productive assets.

Objective 3: To Improve food access to school going children in vulnerable communities by providing them with daily meals to prevent further food insecurity and malnutrition

description: Protracted Relief and Recovery Operations (PRRO) - Ukraine 200953: “Assistance for food insecure and vulnerable populations affected by conflict and loss of livelihoods in eastern Ukraine”.(Allocation of unearmarked funds)
sourceObjects_Organization.name: World Food Programme
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Organization.name: World Food Programme
destinationObjects_Location.name: Ukraine
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Food Security and Livelihood
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Ukraine Humanitarian Response Plan 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Protracted Relief and Recovery Operations (PRRO) - Ukraine 200953: “Assistance for food insecure and vulnerable populations affected by conflict and loss of livelihoods in eastern Ukraine”.
project_text:
Protracted Relief and Recovery Operations (PRRO) - Ukraine 200953: “Assistance for food insecure and vulnerable populations affected by conflict and loss of livelihoods in eastern Ukraine”. After two years of conflict, the security situation in eastern Ukraine remains fragile. The consequences of conflict and political stalemate are felt by individuals and communities throughout Ukraine. An estimated 1.1 million people are in need of food assistance, with many resorting to negative coping mechanisms. The Government continues to face massive challenges, including a deepening economic crisis and the urgent need for social and fiscal reform. Without medium- to long-term interventions, more people will require humanitarian assistance in the months and years to come.

The proposed protracted relief and recovery operation (PRRO) builds on the activities and lessons learned from emergency operation 200765. It is informed by assessments, evaluations and participatory consultations, which have led to a refinement of the program strategy and the choice of transfer modalities. WFP will address the food needs of the most vulnerable people in eastern Ukraine while gradually supporting early recovery. 

The operation is aligned with WFP’s Strategic Plan (2017–2021) and gender and protection policies and guidelines. It is guided by Sustainable Development Goals 2 and 17, fostering partnerships and national plans and strategies to achieve zero hunger.
The operation is in line with the United Nations Development Assistance Framework; contributes to the Government’s Single and Comprehensive Strategy and Action Plan for Agriculture and Rural Development in Ukraine for 2015–2020 by enhancing food security and monitoring systems; and is aligned with national social protection schemes. It also builds on the priorities of the humanitarian response plan and national recovery plans.

Under planned PRRO, over the period January-December 2017, WFP will provide food assistance to 220,000 food insecure people in conflict-affected eastern Ukraine through a combination of food in kind and cash based transfers.

description: Réponse intégrée aux besoins essentiels des populations victimes et affectées par les conflits et les catastrophes au Nord et au Sud du Mali (ECHO/-WF/BUD/2017/91027)
sourceObjects_Organization.name: European Commission's Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection Department
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Organization.name: Acción Contra el Hambre - Spain
destinationObjects_Location.name: Mali
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Mali 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Programme de sécurité alimentaire et de renforcement de la résilience des ménages en insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle, affectées par les chocs agro climatiques et le conflit, dans 20 communes du nord du Mali (Gao, Tombouctou)
reportDetails_organization: European Commission's Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection Department
project_text:
Programme de sécurité alimentaire et de renforcement de la résilience des ménages en insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle, affectées par les chocs agro climatiques et le conflit, dans 20 communes du nord du Mali (Gao, Tombouctou) Cette fiche de proposition se situe dans la droite ligne des axes stratégiques prioritaires du Cluster Sécurité Alimentaire, à savoir : 1) l’assistance coordonnée et intégrée aux personnes en situation d'urgence pour garantir leur survie, 2) le soutien des populations vulnérables à l'insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle pour mieux faire face aux chocs agro climatiques et sécuritaires en renforçant leurs moyens d'existence, 3) le renforcement de capacité des structures et acteurs nationaux pour mieux coordonner les réponses d'urgence et de résilience des populations affectées. Elle fait partie d’un projet multisectoriel plus global intégrant des activités de nutrition et de EHA.
   Résultat 1: Les besoins alimentaires et non alimentaires essentiels de 51 443 ménages en insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle sévère sont couverts à travers une intervention coordonnée et intégrée d’assistance alimentaire et de transferts monétaires multi-usages, dans 20 communes les plus vulnérables des cercles de Tombouctou, Goundam, Salam, Gao et Ansongo
   Résultat 2: Les capacités de préparation, d’adaptation et de renforcement des moyens d´existence face aux chocs agro climatiques et sécuritaires de 12 750 ménages très vulnérables à l’IAN dont 2 550 dirigés par des femmes veuves (20%) et/ou mères d’enfants < 5 ans sont développées
   Résultat 3: Les capacités des structures et acteurs nationaux de coordination des réponses d'urgence et de résilience des populations affectées sont renforcées, ainsi que les capacités techniques des 12 750 ménages bénéficiaires
all_text:

Elle fait partie d’un projet multisectoriel plus global intégrant des activités de nutrition et de EHA.
   Résultat 1: Les besoins alimentaires et non alimentaires essentiels de 51 443 ménages en insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle sévère sont couverts à travers une intervention coordonnée et intégrée d’assistance alimentaire et de transferts monétaires multi-usages, dans 20 communes les plus vulnérables des cercles de Tombouctou, Goundam, Salam, Gao et Ansongo

destinationObjects_Location.name: Somalia
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Somalia 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Building Resilient Livelihoods to Improve Food Security and Nutrition in Somalia
reportDetails_organization: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; Sweden, Government of
project_text:
Building Resilient Livelihoods to Improve Food Security and Nutrition in Somalia 1) Improve households’ immediate access to food through unconditional and conditional transfers to meet the social protection needs of rural communities, including cash-for-work to rehabilitate productive infrastructure.

2) Increase the productive capacity of farmers, agropastoralists, pastoralists and fishers through the provision of seasonally appropriate, climate smart inputs and training.

3) Prevent losses to lives and livelihoods through effective early warning, preparedness and early action ahead of foreseen crises (excluding drought response and famine prevention activities).
all_text:
Building Resilient Livelihoods to Improve Food Security and Nutrition in Somalia Building Resilient Livelihoods to Improve Food Security and Nutrition in Somalia 1) Improve households’ immediate access to food through unconditional and conditional transfers to meet the social protection needs of rural communities, including cash-for-work to rehabilitate productive infrastructure.

2) Increase the productive capacity of farmers, agropastoralists, pastoralists and fishers through the provision of seasonally appropriate, climate smart inputs and training.

3) Prevent losses to lives and livelihoods through effective early warning, preparedness and early action ahead of foreseen crises (excluding drought response and famine prevention activities).

description: Humanitarian Support
sourceObjects_Location.name: Sweden
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Sweden, Government of
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Organization.name: Acción Contra el Hambre - Spain
destinationObjects_Location.name: Mali
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Mali 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Programme de sécurité alimentaire et de renforcement de la résilience des ménages en insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle, affectées par les chocs agro climatiques et le conflit, dans 20 communes du nord du Mali (Gao, Tombouctou)
project_text:
Programme de sécurité alimentaire et de renforcement de la résilience des ménages en insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle, affectées par les chocs agro climatiques et le conflit, dans 20 communes du nord du Mali (Gao, Tombouctou) Cette fiche de proposition se situe dans la droite ligne des axes stratégiques prioritaires du Cluster Sécurité Alimentaire, à savoir : 1) l’assistance coordonnée et intégrée aux personnes en situation d'urgence pour garantir leur survie, 2) le soutien des populations vulnérables à l'insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle pour mieux faire face aux chocs agro climatiques et sécuritaires en renforçant leurs moyens d'existence, 3) le renforcement de capacité des structures et acteurs nationaux pour mieux coordonner les réponses d'urgence et de résilience des populations affectées. Elle fait partie d’un projet multisectoriel plus global intégrant des activités de nutrition et de EHA.
   Résultat 1: Les besoins alimentaires et non alimentaires essentiels de 51 443 ménages en insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle sévère sont couverts à travers une intervention coordonnée et intégrée d’assistance alimentaire et de transferts monétaires multi-usages, dans 20 communes les plus vulnérables des cercles de Tombouctou, Goundam, Salam, Gao et Ansongo
   Résultat 2: Les capacités de préparation, d’adaptation et de renforcement des moyens d´existence face aux chocs agro climatiques et sécuritaires de 12 750 ménages très vulnérables à l’IAN dont 2 550 dirigés par des femmes veuves (20%) et/ou mères d’enfants < 5 ans sont développées
   Résultat 3: Les capacités des structures et acteurs nationaux de coordination des réponses d'urgence et de résilience des populations affectées sont renforcées, ainsi que les capacités techniques des 12 750 ménages bénéficiaires
all_text:
Humanitarian Support Programme de sécurité alimentaire et de renforcement de la résilience des ménages en insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle, affectées par les chocs agro climatiques et le conflit, dans 20 communes du nord du Mali (Gao, Tombouctou) Cette fiche de proposition se situe dans la droite ligne des axes stratégiques prioritaires du Cluster Sécurité Alimentaire, à savoir : 1) l’assistance coordonnée et intégrée aux personnes en situation d'urgence pour garantir leur survie, 2) le soutien des populations vulnérables à l'insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle pour mieux faire face aux chocs agro climatiques et sécuritaires en renforçant leurs moyens d'existence, 3) le renforcement de capacité des structures et acteurs nationaux pour mieux coordonner les réponses d'urgence et de résilience des populations affectées. Elle fait partie d’un projet multisectoriel plus global intégrant des activités de nutrition et de EHA.
   Résultat 1: Les besoins alimentaires et non alimentaires essentiels de 51 443 ménages en insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle sévère sont couverts à travers une intervention coordonnée et intégrée d’assistance alimentaire et de transferts monétaires multi-usages, dans 20 communes les plus vulnérables des cercles de Tombouctou, Goundam, Salam, Gao et Ansongo
   Résultat 2: Les capacités de préparation, d’adaptation et de renforcement des moyens d´existence face aux chocs agro climatiques et sécuritaires de 12 750 ménages très vulnérables à l’IAN dont 2 550 dirigés par des femmes veuves (20%) et/ou mères d’enfants < 5 ans sont développées
   Résultat 3: Les capacités des structures et acteurs nationaux de coordination des réponses d'urgence et de résilience des populations affectées sont renforcées, ainsi que les capacités techniques des 12 750 ménages bénéficiaires

description: Réponse aux besoins alimentaires immédiats des personnes en insécurité alimentaire sévère, y compris les personnes affectées par les catastrophes naturelles et les personnes déplacées par les conflits
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Central Emergency Response Fund
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Organization.name: World Food Programme
destinationObjects_Location.name: Mali
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Mali 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Protracted Relief and Recovery Operation (PRRO 200719) - Responding to immediate food security and nutrition needs
project_text:
Protracted Relief and Recovery Operation (PRRO 200719) - Responding to immediate food security and nutrition needs Working with partners, this operation's objective is to responding to immediate food security of vulnerable populations through food assistance (in kind and cash transfers). Specifically, WFP aims to:
1) Stabilize or improve food consumption over assistance period for targeted households and/or individuals;
2) Maintain emergency-response capacity, protect beneficiaries and promote women’s participation.
3) Address the needs of other food-insecure populations through advocacy and capacity building

description: Supporting life-saving interventions through education to strengthen resilience for vulnerable children (girls and boys), including IDP children, in drought-affected regions.
sourceObjects_Location.name: Somalia
sourceObjects_Organization.name: United Nations Children's Fund
sourceObjects_Plan.name: Somalia 2017
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Education
destinationObjects_Organization.name: United Nations Children's Fund
destinationObjects_Location.name: Somalia
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Education
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Somalia 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Supporting life-saving interventions through education to strengthen resilience for vulnerable children (girls and boys), including IDP children, in drought-affected regions.
project_text:
Supporting life-saving interventions through education to strengthen resilience for vulnerable children (girls and boys), including IDP children, in drought-affected regions. Maintain access to education in emergency settings for 87,500 children (50 % girls) in drought-affected regions in Somaliland, Central South Somalia and Puntland and support the most vulnerable children in communities with life-saving support through education.
This will be achieved through: Access to the newly established temporary learning spaces which include twin wash facilities and water in schools and WASH packages to prevent disease outbreak; Provision of learning and teaching materials; provision of emergency school grants that provide schools autonomy to allocate the grant to the greatest need which can include community-based school feeding and outreach to the most vulnerable children in communities with lifesaving support; community engagement and support; strengthening in the capacity of teachers to provide psychosocial support and protect children; provide cash and non-cash incentives to ensure teachers are retained in schools; Support establishment and capacity strengthening of government-led EiE coordination and response systems.
all_text:
Supporting life-saving interventions through education to strengthen resilience for vulnerable children (girls and boys), including IDP children, in drought-affected regions. Supporting life-saving interventions through education to strengthen resilience for vulnerable children (girls and boys), including IDP children, in drought-affected regions. Maintain access to education in emergency settings for 87,500 children (50 % girls) in drought-affected regions in Somaliland, Central South Somalia and Puntland and support the most vulnerable children in communities with life-saving support through education.
This will be achieved through: Access to the newly established temporary learning spaces which include twin wash facilities and water in schools and WASH packages to prevent disease outbreak; Provision of learning and teaching materials; provision of emergency school grants that provide schools autonomy to allocate the grant to the greatest need which can include community-based school feeding and outreach to the most vulnerable children in communities with lifesaving support; community engagement and support; strengthening in the capacity of teachers to provide psychosocial support and protect children; provide cash and non-cash incentives to ensure teachers are retained in schools; Support establishment and capacity strengthening of government-led EiE coordination and response systems.

description: Providing life-saving food security support to households affected by insecurity in northern Nigeria
sourceObjects_Location.name: Nigeria
sourceObjects_Organization.name: World Food Programme
sourceObjects_Plan.name: Nigeria 2017
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Organization.name: World Food Programme
destinationObjects_Location.name: Nigeria
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Nigeria 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Providing life-saving food security support to households affected by insecurity in northern Nigeria
project_text:
Providing life-saving food security support to households affected by insecurity in northern Nigeria WFP aims at stabilizing or improving food consumption for targeted households and individuals. 
WFP will provide food or cash assistance to 1,129,054 IDPs, returnees and local population in Borno and Yobe State. This includes general food distributions via in-kind food, via cash-based transfers, as well as livelihoods interventions via cash assistance (without overlap figure).

WFP will provide food or cash assistance to 1,129,054 IDPs, returnees and local population in Borno and Yobe State. This includes general food distributions via in-kind food, via cash-based transfers, as well as livelihoods interventions via cash assistance (without overlap figure).

destinationObjects_Project.name: Protection of Conflict Affected People in Gaza Strip (temporary Cash for Work Employment)
project_text:
Protection of Conflict Affected People in Gaza Strip (temporary Cash for Work Employment) The project overall objective: 
“To support vulnerable and food insecure communities in the Gaza Strip by improving economic access to food”

The objective of this project is in line with the Country Strategic Objectives No. 1 and 3: 
I): “The rights of Palestinians under occupation are protected in accordance with IHL and IHRL  
and  
III): Strengthen the ability of acutely-vulnerable Palestinian households to cope with protracted threats and shocks

The project will involve the following activities as indicated in the FSS HRP 2017 project matrix : “Cash-based support”

description: Assistance alimentaire aux personnes plus vulnérables affectées par la crise socioéconomique complexe qui a fortement érodé les moyens d’existence et les aléas climatiques dans les 12 provinces particulièrement affectées du pays.
sourceObjects_Location.name: Burundi
sourceObjects_Organization.name: World Food Programme
sourceObjects_Plan.name: Burundi 2017
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Organization.name: World Food Programme
destinationObjects_Location.name: Burundi
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Sécurité Alimentaire
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Burundi 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Assistance alimentaire  aux personnes plus vulnérables affectées par la crise socioéconomique complexe qui a fortement érodé les moyens d’existence et les aléas climatiques dans les 12 provinces particulièrement affectées du pays.
project_text:
Assistance alimentaire  aux personnes plus vulnérables affectées par la crise socioéconomique complexe qui a fortement érodé les moyens d’existence et les aléas climatiques dans les 12 provinces particulièrement affectées du pays. Objectif stratégique: Assurer l'accès à l'alimentation des ménages plus vulnérables (y compris entre autres les PDIs ménages d’accueil, retournés, ménages dirigés par des veuves et orphelins) à travers des distributions en vivres et ou en cash. 

Objectif specifique1 :

Apporter une assistance en vivres et/ou transfert monétaire non conditionnel à plus de 327.000 personnes en insécurité alimentaire sévère. 

Objectif specifique2 : 
Appuyer la relance de la production agricole de près 430 000 personnes à travers une distribution de ration de protection des semences et protection de BV

description: Improve access to emergency livelihood opportunities for the conflict affected IDPs and host communities
sourceObjects_Location.name: Iraq
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Iraq Humanitarian Fund
sourceObjects_Plan.name: Iraq 2017
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Early Recovery
destinationObjects_Organization.name: Secours Islamique France
destinationObjects_Location.name: Iraq
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Emergency Livelihoods - Social Cohesion
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Iraq 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Maintain the resilience of IDPs and host communities and enable them to cope with the impact of crisis, in their chosen locations in Iraq, through immediate access to income for vulnerable families and social awareness, in areas at high risk of tensions
project_text:
Maintain the resilience of IDPs and host communities and enable them to cope with the impact of crisis, in their chosen locations in Iraq, through immediate access to income for vulnerable families and social awareness, in areas at high risk of tensions Overall objective: Help to replace lost assets and generate urgent cash income for highly vulnerable families in priority locations


Category of project’s beneficiaries:
This project will mainly target the extremely vulnerable resident families and out-of-camp IDPs, priorities will be given to those who have no access to PDS, markets, agriculture assets, emergency cash assistance and other forms of food assistance in hard-to-reach areas in Ninewa and Anbar province

The proposed project is directly linked with the first line response of EL cluster, it will stabilize social cohesion through immediate access to income for vulnerable families at high risk of tension. The project will aim at maintaining social cohesion at the community level through support to community assets increasing access to regular income and opening channels for dialogue.

The activities of the project will directly produce outputs that fit with the 1st line response strategy through targeting the extremely vulnerable IDPs, returnees and residents in conflict areas with livelihood opportunities to generate income for their families and minimize the risk of tension between them and their hosting communities.

First line activities will be undertaken immediately after having the project funded to respond to the new wave of displacement, returns or improved access to residents in conflict areas previously un-accessible. The First Line response is centred at the household level to mitigate the main risks of livelihood and income loss and promote tolerance social. This will be achieved through the provision of immediate access to income and assets replacement (primarily lost tools) for vulnerable households and social awareness activities.
all_text:

Category of project’s beneficiaries:

description: Improvement of WASH environment for Iraqi IDPs, Returnees and Host communities
sourceObjects_Location.name: Japan
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Japan, Government of
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Water Sanitation Hygiene
destinationObjects_Organization.name: Japan Emergency NGO
destinationObjects_Location.name: Iraq
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: WASH
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Iraq 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Sustained full response WASH services in Mamilyan Camp with improvements in access to WASH facilities for disabled people and grey water drainage; Rehabilitation and construction of boreholes in Sinjar City
project_text:
Sustained full response WASH services in Mamilyan Camp with improvements in access to WASH facilities for disabled people and grey water drainage; Rehabilitation and construction of boreholes in Sinjar City 1 - JEN aims to continue to improve the personal hygiene and environmental
sanitation in Mamilyan Camp through the continued provision of a full WASH
package to all camp residents (partial funding likely); including bi-monthly
distribution of hygiene kits (consumable), annual distribution of WASH kit items
(durable) via a voucher to be used at a temporary shop in the camp, maintenance of
household level water and sewage systems, hygiene promotion activities with emphasis of engagement and targeting of women, solid waste removal and desludging of septic pits and quality/quantity monitoring of
water. During 2017 JEN would like to accomplish two additional projects in
Mamilyan Camp (unfunded): providing additional WASH support to families with
disabled members in order to improve access to toilets and shower facilities, this
will involve installing access ramps, pull bars and handicapped toilets on a case by
case basis and install fencing along the open grey water channel which often
becomes blocked leading to poor drainage of waste and storm waters from the
camp.

2 – JEN aims to restore sustainable water delivery in Sinjar City through the
rehabilitation and pipe extension of one existing but war-damaged borehole and the
construction of a new borehole. (unfunded)
all_text:
Improvement of WASH environment for Iraqi IDPs, Returnees and Host communities Sustained full response WASH services in Mamilyan Camp with improvements in access to WASH facilities for disabled people and grey water drainage; Rehabilitation and construction of boreholes in Sinjar City 1 - JEN aims to continue to improve the personal hygiene and environmental
sanitation in Mamilyan Camp through the continued provision of a full WASH
package to all camp residents (partial funding likely); including bi-monthly
distribution of hygiene kits (consumable), annual distribution of WASH kit items
(durable) via a voucher to be used at a temporary shop in the camp, maintenance of

water. During 2017 JEN would like to accomplish two additional projects in
Mamilyan Camp (unfunded): providing additional WASH support to families with
disabled members in order to improve access to toilets and shower facilities, this
will involve installing access ramps, pull bars and handicapped toilets on a case by
case basis and install fencing along the open grey water channel which often
becomes blocked leading to poor drainage of waste and storm waters from the
camp.

2 – JEN aims to restore sustainable water delivery in Sinjar City through the
rehabilitation and pipe extension of one existing but war-damaged borehole and the
construction of a new borehole. (unfunded)

description: Integrated emergency shelter assistance to Palestinian refugees from Syria, Libya, Yemen and Iraq in the Gaza Strip.
sourceObjects_Location.name: Occupied Palestinian Territory
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Occupied Palestinian Territory Humanitarian Fund
sourceObjects_Plan.name: occupied Palestinian territory 2017
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Emergency Shelter and NFI
destinationObjects_Organization.name: Agency for Technical Cooperation and Development
destinationObjects_Location.name: Occupied Palestinian Territory
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Shelter NFIs
destinationObjects_Plan.name: occupied Palestinian territory 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Integrated emergency assistance to Palestinian refugees from Syria, Libya, Yemen and Iraq in the Gaza Strip.
project_text:
Integrated emergency assistance to Palestinian refugees from Syria, Libya, Yemen and Iraq in the Gaza Strip. The project will aim at providing life-saving emergency assistance to displaced Palestinian refugees who fled from conflict zones in Syria, Libya, Iraq and Yemen back into the Gaza Strip. The proposed intervention will support them through Transitional Shelter Cash Assistance and direct access to food through vouchers, while also building the capacity of their representatives to provide basic protection services.

Considering the extreme vulnerability identified among some targeted beneficiaries, the project will have lifesaving impact. The proposed assistance is time critical, in so far as the assessments conducted reveal that the coping capacities of targeted populations is exhausted, and that any further deterioration of their vulnerability could have lethal consequences. Eventually, by covering the most basic and urgent needs of beneficiaries, it will the project will be critically enabling for other actors to implement highly needed longer term projects, in particular in the education, health and protection sectors.

The proposed action is fully in line with the priorities identified in the HRP and aligns in particular with the following objective and results:

Strategic objective 3: “Strengthen the ability of acutely vulnerable Palestinian households to cope with protracted threats and shock”. 
Shelter Cluster Result 3 “Mitigate the risk and immediate effects of displacement due to natural disasters or conflict through preparedness and appropriate emergency shelter interventions”.
Food Security Sector Result 2: “Households suffering from lack of access to food are able to meet their basic food needs”, through the  activity code 3.2 “Food voucher support”.
Protection Cluster Result 2: “The effects of the occupation and conflict related violence are prevented and mitigated.”
all_text:
Integrated emergency shelter assistance to Palestinian refugees from Syria, Libya, Yemen and Iraq in the Gaza Strip. description: Restoration of economic activity after Hurricane Irma in the Caribbean through debris and waste management
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Central Emergency Response Fund
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Early Recovery
destinationObjects_Organization.name: United Nations Development Programme
destinationObjects_Location.name: Antigua and Barbuda
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Early Recovery
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Hurricane Irma: Regional Response Plan for the Caribbean Region (Sep to Dec 2017)
destinationObjects_Project.name: Early recovery
destinationObjects_Emergency.name: CARIBBEAN - Hurricane Irma - September 2017
project_text:
Early recovery • Debris management of damaged houses and community infrastructure (removal, reuse and
recycling of construction materials).
• Organic waste management of palm trees or other waste left by the strong winds. Prevent
contamination of clean water sources, soil and others. Adequate management of dump sites
(many areas might be flooded).
• Short term employment opportunities for affected families. This approach will help to ensure that
affected families become direct recovery agents while serving to inject cash in the communities
and facilitate the procurement and distribution of tools, building supplies, equipment, training
and technical capacity (engineers, architects).
• Rehabilitation of basic services and community infrastructure such as electricity, water supplies,
security or others.
• Livelihoods: support key economic sectors, including markets and micro and small enterprises to
revive economic activities.
• Support to core government functions and coordination at local, regional and national level
depending upon request.
• Technical assistance and implementing capacity in areas related to damage and needs assessments
and support to authorities in the formulation of recovery strategies focusing on resilience
and Climate Change adaptation, Building Back Better and the achievement of the Sustainable
Development Goals.
all_text:
Restoration of economic activity after Hurricane Irma in the Caribbean through debris and waste management Early recovery • Debris management of damaged houses and community infrastructure (removal, reuse and
recycling of construction materials).
• Organic waste management of palm trees or other waste left by the strong winds. Prevent
contamination of clean water sources, soil and others. Adequate management of dump sites
(many areas might be flooded).
• Short term employment opportunities for affected families. This approach will help to ensure that
affected families become direct recovery agents while serving to inject cash in the communities
and facilitate the procurement and distribution of tools, building supplies, equipment, training
and technical capacity (engineers, architects).
• Rehabilitation of basic services and community infrastructure such as electricity, water supplies,
security or others.
• Livelihoods: support key economic sectors, including markets and micro and small enterprises to
revive economic activities.
• Support to core government functions and coordination at local, regional and national level
depending upon request.
• Technical assistance and implementing capacity in areas related to damage and needs assessments
and support to authorities in the formulation of recovery strategies focusing on resilience
and Climate Change adaptation, Building Back Better and the achievement of the Sustainable
Development Goals.

description: Integrated emergency WASH and MPC response to most vulnerable families in South Central Somalia (ECHO/-HF/BUD/2018/91005)
sourceObjects_Organization.name: European Commission's Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection Department
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Water Sanitation Hygiene
destinationObjects_Organization.name: Polish Humanitarian Action
destinationObjects_Location.name: Somalia
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Water, Sanitation and Hygiene
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Somalia Humanitarian Response Plan 2018
destinationObjects_Project.name: Integrated WASH and FSL response to most vulnerable families in Banaadir and Middle Shabelle
reportDetails_organization: European Commission's Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection Department
project_text: Integrated WASH and FSL response to most vulnerable families in Banaadir and Middle Shabelle The project will provide an integrated WASH and FSL emergency response to the most vulnerable crisis affected households. These would predominantly be newly displaced families settling in IDP camps along Mogadishu - Afgoye road, but also communities affected by disease outbreaks, inter-community conflict, drought and  floods residing in  Middle Shabelle. The project's aim is also to mainstream camp management objectives, to address protection issues, and to increase accountability to beneficiaries and empower marginalized groups. For WASH, the dominant sector objective is to provide access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene for people in emergency (Objective 2) combined with WASH emergency preparedness (Objective 1) especially in terms of flood risk reduction. Lastly, the sustainable expansion of safe water infrastructure (Objective 3) as an exit strategy for water trucking and AWD response. As access to water, sanitation and food remain priority needs, the project will provide improved access to food (Objective 1) for families that are classified on the food consumption score as IPC 3 or 4. Multipurpose cash will be used as modality. Camp coordination, camp management and governance (CCCM) objectives will be mainstreamed throughout the project, and will focusing on strengthening community self-management to promote durable solutions for displaced people in sites and improve community engagement, participation, living conditions and safe access to services.
all_text: Integrated emergency WASH and MPC response to most vulnerable families in South Central Somalia (ECHO/-HF/BUD/2018/91005) Integrated WASH and FSL response to most vulnerable families in Banaadir and Middle Shabelle The project will provide an integrated WASH and FSL emergency response to the most vulnerable crisis affected households. These would predominantly be newly displaced families settling in IDP camps along Mogadishu - Afgoye road, but also communities affected by disease outbreaks, inter-community conflict, drought and  floods residing in  Middle Shabelle. The project's aim is also to mainstream camp management objectives, to address protection issues, and to increase accountability to beneficiaries and empower marginalized groups. For WASH, the dominant sector objective is to provide access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene for people in emergency (Objective 2) combined with WASH emergency preparedness (Objective 1) especially in terms of flood risk reduction. Lastly, the sustainable expansion of safe water infrastructure (Objective 3) as an exit strategy for water trucking and AWD response. As access to water, sanitation and food remain priority needs, the project will provide improved access to food (Objective 1) for families that are classified on the food consumption score as IPC 3 or 4. Multipurpose cash will be used as modality. Camp coordination, camp management and governance (CCCM) objectives will be mainstreamed throughout the project, and will focusing on strengthening community self-management to promote durable solutions for displaced people in sites and improve community engagement, participation, living conditions and safe access to services.

destinationObjects_Emergency.name: Syrian Arab Republic - Civil Unrest (from 2012)
reportDetails_organization: United States of America, Government of; World Food Programme; United States of America, Government of
project_text:
Provision of general food assistance in the form of regular in-kind monthly food rations and ready-to-eat rations in the initial phase of displacement. The overall objective of the project: saving lives, sustaining lives and protecting livelihoods through the provision of emergency and regular food assistance to the most vulnerable families affected by the crisis. This contributes to SO1.
Based on the Food and Agriculture Sector 2018 sector strategy, approximately 6.5 million people are facing acute food insecurity with an additional 4 million at risk of falling into a situation of being food insecure. IDPs and people in besieged and Hard to Reach areas in addition to female headed households are between the most vulnerable groups that need food assistance to meet their minimum consumption needs. Women are increasingly becoming family breadwinners, heading more than third of the households.  Assistance to vulnerable groups with focus on female headed household will be prioritized. In addition, if the situation changed allowing a significant number of returnees among the IDPs and refugees, WFP will consider this group in the emergency general food assistance. WFP will consider various modalities as appropriate: including in-kind food assistance (Main modality for GFD) as well as cash based transfer (CBT). 
Emergency general food assistance is one of the four main activities/projects of WFP in 2018.  It will be complemented by i) nutrition project, targeting women and children to prevent and respond to undernutrition, ii) livelihood project to re build livelihood and resilience, and iii) school meals project, targeting pupils to support their learning. 

The emergency general food assistance project is aligned with the objectives 1 and 4 of the Food Security Cluster:
1. Improve the food security status of assessed food insecure people by emergency life saving and regular life sustaining food assistance
4: Strengthen the effectiveness and quality of the WoS response based on evidence, capacity building and strong coordination within the Food Security and Agriculture Sector and cross sectors.
all_text:
Humanitarian Assistance for Food Security Sector (USAID/FFP) Provision of general food assistance in the form of regular in-kind monthly food rations and ready-to-eat rations in the initial phase of displacement. The overall objective of the project: saving lives, sustaining lives and protecting livelihoods through the provision of emergency and regular food assistance to the most vulnerable families affected by the crisis. This contributes to SO1.
Based on the Food and Agriculture Sector 2018 sector strategy, approximately 6.5 million people are facing acute food insecurity with an additional 4 million at risk of falling into a situation of being food insecure. IDPs and people in besieged and Hard to Reach areas in addition to female headed households are between the most vulnerable groups that need food assistance to meet their minimum consumption needs. Women are increasingly becoming family breadwinners, heading more than third of the households.  Assistance to vulnerable groups with focus on female headed household will be prioritized. In addition, if the situation changed allowing a significant number of returnees among the IDPs and refugees, WFP will consider this group in the emergency general food assistance. WFP will consider various modalities as appropriate: including in-kind food assistance (Main modality for GFD) as well as cash based transfer (CBT). 
Emergency general food assistance is one of the four main activities/projects of WFP in 2018.  It will be complemented by i) nutrition project, targeting women and children to prevent and respond to undernutrition, ii) livelihood project to re build livelihood and resilience, and iii) school meals project, targeting pupils to support their learning. 

The emergency general food assistance project is aligned with the objectives 1 and 4 of the Food Security Cluster:
1. Improve the food security status of assessed food insecure people by emergency life saving and regular life sustaining food assistance
4: Strengthen the effectiveness and quality of the WoS response based on evidence, capacity building and strong coordination within the Food Security and Agriculture Sector and cross sectors.

description: Strenghtening OCHA presence and capacities in Niger, especially in the regions of Diffa and Tillabery (ECHO/-WF/BUD/2018/91039)
sourceObjects_Organization.name: European Commission's Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection Department
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Coordination and support services
destinationObjects_Organization.name: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
destinationObjects_Location.name: Niger
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Coordination and Support Services
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Niger Plan de Réponse Humanitaire 2018
destinationObjects_Project.name: Strengthening humanitarian coordination, advocacy and quality of humanitarian assistance
reportDetails_organization: European Commission's Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection Department
project_text: Strengthening humanitarian coordination, advocacy and quality of humanitarian assistance (i) expanding humanitarian access to deliver life-saving assistance and protection in Diffa, a complex operating environment where the security situation remains volatile; (ii) coordinate the provision of humanitarian assistance in other parts of the country during peaks of malnutrition, food insecurity, epidemics and  flooding; (iii) establishing an efficient humanitarian coordination mechanism in Diffa, (iv) optimizing the cooperation with the Government of Niger, capitalizing on their willingness to take the lead on humanitarian issues while considering how to further support them in terms of capacity building; (v) ensuring adequate funding for humanitarian activities in all humanitarian sectors, including by working closely with donors towards more support and funding tools to national  responders, and the scaling up of cash-based programming.

description: Improvement of WASH environment in newly liberated areas
sourceObjects_Location.name: Japan
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Japan, Government of
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Water Sanitation Hygiene
destinationObjects_Organization.name: Japan Emergency NGO
destinationObjects_Location.name: Iraq
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: WASH
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Iraq 2017
destinationObjects_Project.name: Sustained full response WASH services in Mamilyan Camp with improvements in access to WASH facilities for disabled people and grey water drainage; Rehabilitation and construction of boreholes in Sinjar City
project_text:
Sustained full response WASH services in Mamilyan Camp with improvements in access to WASH facilities for disabled people and grey water drainage; Rehabilitation and construction of boreholes in Sinjar City 1 - JEN aims to continue to improve the personal hygiene and environmental
sanitation in Mamilyan Camp through the continued provision of a full WASH
package to all camp residents (partial funding likely); including bi-monthly
distribution of hygiene kits (consumable), annual distribution of WASH kit items
(durable) via a voucher to be used at a temporary shop in the camp, maintenance of
household level water and sewage systems, hygiene promotion activities with emphasis of engagement and targeting of women, solid waste removal and desludging of septic pits and quality/quantity monitoring of
water. During 2017 JEN would like to accomplish two additional projects in
Mamilyan Camp (unfunded): providing additional WASH support to families with
disabled members in order to improve access to toilets and shower facilities, this
will involve installing access ramps, pull bars and handicapped toilets on a case by
case basis and install fencing along the open grey water channel which often
becomes blocked leading to poor drainage of waste and storm waters from the
camp.

2 – JEN aims to restore sustainable water delivery in Sinjar City through the
rehabilitation and pipe extension of one existing but war-damaged borehole and the
construction of a new borehole. (unfunded)
all_text:
Improvement of WASH environment in newly liberated areas Sustained full response WASH services in Mamilyan Camp with improvements in access to WASH facilities for disabled people and grey water drainage; Rehabilitation and construction of boreholes in Sinjar City 1 - JEN aims to continue to improve the personal hygiene and environmental
sanitation in Mamilyan Camp through the continued provision of a full WASH
package to all camp residents (partial funding likely); including bi-monthly
distribution of hygiene kits (consumable), annual distribution of WASH kit items
(durable) via a voucher to be used at a temporary shop in the camp, maintenance of
household level water and sewage systems, hygiene promotion activities with emphasis of engagement and targeting of women, solid waste removal and desludging of septic pits and quality/quantity monitoring of
water. During 2017 JEN would like to accomplish two additional projects in
Mamilyan Camp (unfunded): providing additional WASH support to families with
disabled members in order to improve access to toilets and shower facilities, this
will involve installing access ramps, pull bars and handicapped toilets on a case by
case basis and install fencing along the open grey water channel which often
becomes blocked leading to poor drainage of waste and storm waters from the
camp.

2 – JEN aims to restore sustainable water delivery in Sinjar City through the
rehabilitation and pipe extension of one existing but war-damaged borehole and the
construction of a new borehole. (unfunded)

destinationObjects_Project.name: A direct intervention to provide sustainable low-cost cash-based shelters and essential non-food items to the most vulnerable IDPs in central equatoria and jonglei regions in South Sudan.
project_text: A direct intervention to provide sustainable low-cost cash-based shelters and essential non-food items to the most vulnerable IDPs in central equatoria and jonglei regions in South Sudan. To ensure that the most vulnerable conflict-affected individuals are provided with the tools to lead a dignified life through the provison of sustainable low cost, cash-based shelters, in-kind shelter materials, essential non-food items.                                                                                                              Program activities that will ensure community participation and positively improve their resilience and copying mechanisms in the implementation and monitoring processes

description: (GAZA) Country Strategic Plan for food assistance to the poor and severely food insecure population in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip
sourceObjects_Location.name: Japan
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Japan, Government of
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Organization.name: World Food Programme
destinationObjects_Location.name: Occupied Palestinian Territory
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Food Security Sector
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Occupied Palestinian Territory Humanitarian Response Strategy 2018
destinationObjects_Project.name: Country Strategic Plan for food assistance to the poor and severely food insecure population in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip
project_text:
Country Strategic Plan for food assistance to the poor and severely food insecure population in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip WFP is committed to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and is guided by a strategic, programmatic and governance instrument to operationalize its plan and achieve its project objectives to: 
• End Hunger by protecting access to food and by improving dietary diversity;
• Support the implementation of the SDGs by enhancing the capacities of national institutions to implement food security strategies and operations;
This project directly contributes to strategic objectives two and three of the Humanitarian Response Plan 2018 2020, by meeting the basic food needs of severely vulnerable Palestinians and by improving their dietary diversity. 
WFP’s interventions focus on high food insecurity levels, including the malnutrition levels recorded by national surveys. By assisting the poor and severely food insecure Palestinian households in Gaza and Bedouin and herding communities in West Bank’s Area C, and by disseminating information on food and nutrition practices, WFP addresses the basic needs of vulnerable Palestinians and tackles one of the or root causes of some of the food insecurity levels recorded by the government institutions.
These interventions aim at improving the overall food security levels including nutrition and health status of the vulnerable Palestinians and therefore at increasing their coping abilities to sudden shocks in the market for access to food. 
The project also contributes to the Food Security Sector’s three objectives as well as to the National Policy Agenda 2017-2022 (policies on escaping poverty and strengthening social protection as well as meeting the basic needs of the communities) to ensure that the vulnerable Palestinians households basic food needs are met, by assisting households in enhancing their food security levels and by strengthening national institutions in implementing food security strategies and social security safety net programs to best identify and target food insecure and vulnerable Palestinians.

The project also contributes to the Food Security Sector’s three objectives as well as to the National Policy Agenda 2017-2022 (policies on escaping poverty and strengthening social protection as well as meeting the basic needs of the communities) to ensure that the vulnerable Palestinians households basic food needs are met, by assisting households in enhancing their food security levels and by strengthening national institutions in implementing food security strategies and social security safety net programs to best identify and target food insecure and vulnerable Palestinians.
all_text:
(WEST BANK) Country Strategic Plan for food assistance to the poor and severely food insecure population in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip (WEST BANK) (Providing critical food assistance to vulnerable poor and food insecure non-refugee Palestinians in Gaza & the West Bank) (Allocation from unearmarked contributions to WFP) Country Strategic Plan for food assistance to the poor and severely food insecure population in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip WFP is committed to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and is guided by a strategic, programmatic and governance instrument to operationalize its plan and achieve its project objectives to: 
• End Hunger by protecting access to food and by improving dietary diversity;
• Support the implementation of the SDGs by enhancing the capacities of national institutions to implement food security strategies and operations;
This project directly contributes to strategic objectives two and three of the Humanitarian Response Plan 2018 2020, by meeting the basic food needs of severely vulnerable Palestinians and by improving their dietary diversity. 
WFP’s interventions focus on high food insecurity levels, including the malnutrition levels recorded by national surveys. By assisting the poor and severely food insecure Palestinian households in Gaza and Bedouin and herding communities in West Bank’s Area C, and by disseminating information on food and nutrition practices, WFP addresses the basic needs of vulnerable Palestinians and tackles one of the or root causes of some of the food insecurity levels recorded by the government institutions.
These interventions aim at improving the overall food security levels including nutrition and health status of the vulnerable Palestinians and therefore at increasing their coping abilities to sudden shocks in the market for access to food. 
The project also contributes to the Food Security Sector’s three objectives as well as to the National Policy Agenda 2017-2022 (policies on escaping poverty and strengthening social protection as well as meeting the basic needs of the communities) to ensure that the vulnerable Palestinians households basic food needs are met, by assisting households in enhancing their food security levels and by strengthening national institutions in implementing food security strategies and social security safety net programs to best identify and target food insecure and vulnerable Palestinians.

destinationObjects_Project.name: Child Protection support to children affected by the conflict and their families
project_text:
Child Protection support to children affected by the conflict and their families Cluster Objective 1:
Provide protection assistance, including community-based support,
for highly vulnerable displaced persons living in camp and non-camp
settings, thereby enabling them to enjoy their rights
Cluster Objective 2:
Provide protection assistance, including community-based support,
for highly vulnerable persons, to facilitate voluntary, safe, nondiscriminatory
and sustainable returns
Cluster Objective 3:
Deliver immediate support to newly displaced persons by facilitating
access to safety and providing protection assistance
Cluster Objective 4
Provide assistance to vulnerable individuals living in mixed populations areas with support to access government social protection systems, and assist with the provision of other specialised protection services.

description: Humanitarian aid
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Private (individuals & organizations)
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Organization.name: World Food Programme
destinationObjects_Location.name: Syrian Arab Republic
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Syrian Arab Republic Humanitarian Response Plan 2018
destinationObjects_Project.name: Provision of general food assistance in the form of regular in-kind monthly food rations and ready-to-eat rations in the initial phase of displacement.
destinationObjects_Emergency.name: Syrian Arab Republic - Civil Unrest (from 2012)
project_text:
Provision of general food assistance in the form of regular in-kind monthly food rations and ready-to-eat rations in the initial phase of displacement. The overall objective of the project: saving lives, sustaining lives and protecting livelihoods through the provision of emergency and regular food assistance to the most vulnerable families affected by the crisis. This contributes to SO1.
Based on the Food and Agriculture Sector 2018 sector strategy, approximately 6.5 million people are facing acute food insecurity with an additional 4 million at risk of falling into a situation of being food insecure. IDPs and people in besieged and Hard to Reach areas in addition to female headed households are between the most vulnerable groups that need food assistance to meet their minimum consumption needs. Women are increasingly becoming family breadwinners, heading more than third of the households.  Assistance to vulnerable groups with focus on female headed household will be prioritized. In addition, if the situation changed allowing a significant number of returnees among the IDPs and refugees, WFP will consider this group in the emergency general food assistance. WFP will consider various modalities as appropriate: including in-kind food assistance (Main modality for GFD) as well as cash based transfer (CBT). 
Emergency general food assistance is one of the four main activities/projects of WFP in 2018.  It will be complemented by i) nutrition project, targeting women and children to prevent and respond to undernutrition, ii) livelihood project to re build livelihood and resilience, and iii) school meals project, targeting pupils to support their learning. 

The emergency general food assistance project is aligned with the objectives 1 and 4 of the Food Security Cluster:
1. Improve the food security status of assessed food insecure people by emergency life saving and regular life sustaining food assistance
4: Strengthen the effectiveness and quality of the WoS response based on evidence, capacity building and strong coordination within the Food Security and Agriculture Sector and cross sectors.

destinationObjects_Location.name: Syrian Arab Republic
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Syrian Arab Republic Humanitarian Response Plan 2018
destinationObjects_Project.name: Provision of general food assistance in the form of regular in-kind monthly food rations and ready-to-eat rations in the initial phase of displacement.
destinationObjects_Emergency.name: Syrian Arab Republic - Civil Unrest (from 2012)
project_text:
Provision of general food assistance in the form of regular in-kind monthly food rations and ready-to-eat rations in the initial phase of displacement. The overall objective of the project: saving lives, sustaining lives and protecting livelihoods through the provision of emergency and regular food assistance to the most vulnerable families affected by the crisis. This contributes to SO1.
Based on the Food and Agriculture Sector 2018 sector strategy, approximately 6.5 million people are facing acute food insecurity with an additional 4 million at risk of falling into a situation of being food insecure. IDPs and people in besieged and Hard to Reach areas in addition to female headed households are between the most vulnerable groups that need food assistance to meet their minimum consumption needs. Women are increasingly becoming family breadwinners, heading more than third of the households.  Assistance to vulnerable groups with focus on female headed household will be prioritized. In addition, if the situation changed allowing a significant number of returnees among the IDPs and refugees, WFP will consider this group in the emergency general food assistance. WFP will consider various modalities as appropriate: including in-kind food assistance (Main modality for GFD) as well as cash based transfer (CBT). 
Emergency general food assistance is one of the four main activities/projects of WFP in 2018.  It will be complemented by i) nutrition project, targeting women and children to prevent and respond to undernutrition, ii) livelihood project to re build livelihood and resilience, and iii) school meals project, targeting pupils to support their learning. 

The emergency general food assistance project is aligned with the objectives 1 and 4 of the Food Security Cluster:
1. Improve the food security status of assessed food insecure people by emergency life saving and regular life sustaining food assistance
4: Strengthen the effectiveness and quality of the WoS response based on evidence, capacity building and strong coordination within the Food Security and Agriculture Sector and cross sectors.

This contributes to SO1.
Based on the Food and Agriculture Sector 2018 sector strategy, approximately 6.5 million people are facing acute food insecurity with an additional 4 million at risk of falling into a situation of being food insecure. IDPs and people in besieged and Hard to Reach areas in addition to female headed households are between the most vulnerable groups that need food assistance to meet their minimum consumption needs. Women are increasingly becoming family breadwinners, heading more than third of the households.  Assistance to vulnerable groups with focus on female headed household will be prioritized. In addition, if the situation changed allowing a significant number of returnees among the IDPs and refugees, WFP will consider this group in the emergency general food assistance. WFP will consider various modalities as appropriate: including in-kind food assistance (Main modality for GFD) as well as cash based transfer (CBT). 
Emergency general food assistance is one of the four main activities/projects of WFP in 2018.  It will be complemented by i) nutrition project, targeting women and children to prevent and respond to undernutrition, ii) livelihood project to re build livelihood and resilience, and iii) school meals project, targeting pupils to support their learning. 

The emergency general food assistance project is aligned with the objectives 1 and 4 of the Food Security Cluster:
1. Improve the food security status of assessed food insecure people by emergency life saving and regular life sustaining food assistance
4: Strengthen the effectiveness and quality of the WoS response based on evidence, capacity building and strong coordination within the Food Security and Agriculture Sector and cross sectors.

description: Support livelihoods opportunities for highly vulnerable families in areas of return in Kirkuk governorate.
sourceObjects_Location.name: Iraq
sourceObjects_Organization.name: Iraq Humanitarian Fund
sourceObjects_Plan.name: Iraq Humanitarian Response Plan 2018
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Early Recovery
destinationObjects_Organization.name: Relief International
destinationObjects_Location.name: Iraq
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Emergency Livelihoods
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Iraq Humanitarian Response Plan 2018
destinationObjects_Project.name: Support livelihoods opportunities for highly vulnerable families (returnees, host communities and IDPs) in Kirkuk and Anbar
project_text:
Support livelihoods opportunities for highly vulnerable families (returnees, host communities and IDPs) in Kirkuk and Anbar 1. Providing immediate access to income to support highly vulnerable IDPs to return to their original communities and strengthen their ability to improve current living conditions, to avoid negative coping mechanisms and to become self sufficient. Specific attention will be given to women/elderly headed households, people without income source who are moving out of closing camps, facing new or secondary displacement, youth, SGBV victims and people with disabilities.

2. To enhance the economic empowerment and social roles of women in target areas, while paying particular attention to any tensions that might be raised within households and the community.

3. Re establishing lost livelihoods to assist vulnerable IDPs to return to their communities and strengthen their resilience.

4. Improving access to income for people who are not adequately covered by social protection systems in order to support them to maintain a minimum living standard in the absence of social assistance. Specific attention will be given to assist vulnerable IDPs returning to their home of origin.
all_text:
Support livelihoods opportunities for highly vulnerable families in areas of return in Kirkuk governorate. Support livelihoods opportunities for highly vulnerable families (returnees, host communities and IDPs) in Kirkuk and Anbar 1. Providing immediate access to income to support highly vulnerable IDPs to return to their original communities and strengthen their ability to improve current living conditions, to avoid negative coping mechanisms and to become self sufficient. Specific attention will be given to women/elderly headed households, people without income source who are moving out of closing camps, facing new or secondary displacement, youth, SGBV victims and people with disabilities.

2. To enhance the economic empowerment and social roles of women in target areas, while paying particular attention to any tensions that might be raised within households and the community.

3. Re establishing lost livelihoods to assist vulnerable IDPs to return to their communities and strengthen their resilience.

4. Improving access to income for people who are not adequately covered by social protection systems in order to support them to maintain a minimum living standard in the absence of social assistance. Specific attention will be given to assist vulnerable IDPs returning to their home of origin.

description: (GAZA) Food Assistance to Vulnerable Food-Insecure Non- Refugee Populations In the Gaza Strip (part of ECHO/PSE/BUD/2018/91006)
sourceObjects_Organization.name: European Commission's Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection Department
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Food Security
destinationObjects_Organization.name: World Food Programme
destinationObjects_Location.name: Occupied Palestinian Territory
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Food Security Sector
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Occupied Palestinian Territory Humanitarian Response Strategy 2018
destinationObjects_Project.name: Country Strategic Plan for food assistance to the poor and severely food insecure population in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip
reportDetails_organization: European Commission's Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection Department
project_text:
Country Strategic Plan for food assistance to the poor and severely food insecure population in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip WFP is committed to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and is guided by a strategic, programmatic and governance instrument to operationalize its plan and achieve its project objectives to: 
• End Hunger by protecting access to food and by improving dietary diversity;
• Support the implementation of the SDGs by enhancing the capacities of national institutions to implement food security strategies and operations;
This project directly contributes to strategic objectives two and three of the Humanitarian Response Plan 2018 2020, by meeting the basic food needs of severely vulnerable Palestinians and by improving their dietary diversity. 
WFP’s interventions focus on high food insecurity levels, including the malnutrition levels recorded by national surveys. By assisting the poor and severely food insecure Palestinian households in Gaza and Bedouin and herding communities in West Bank’s Area C, and by disseminating information on food and nutrition practices, WFP addresses the basic needs of vulnerable Palestinians and tackles one of the or root causes of some of the food insecurity levels recorded by the government institutions.
These interventions aim at improving the overall food security levels including nutrition and health status of the vulnerable Palestinians and therefore at increasing their coping abilities to sudden shocks in the market for access to food. 
The project also contributes to the Food Security Sector’s three objectives as well as to the National Policy Agenda 2017-2022 (policies on escaping poverty and strengthening social protection as well as meeting the basic needs of the communities) to ensure that the vulnerable Palestinians households basic food needs are met, by assisting households in enhancing their food security levels and by strengthening national institutions in implementing food security strategies and social security safety net programs to best identify and target food insecure and vulnerable Palestinians.

project_text:
Child Protection in Emergency assistance to displaced children and youths in Hawija and Dabes districts - Kirkuk Governorate The preset project contribute to the 2018 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) and the Child protection cluster objectives through;
1- Provide protection assistance, including community-based support, for highly vulnerable persons, to facilitate voluntary, safe, nondiscriminatory and sustainable returns
2- Deliver immediate support to newly displaced persons by providing specialized and targeted protection assistance
3- Provide assistance to vulnerable individuals living in mixed populations areas with support to access government social protection systems, and assist with the provision of other specialized protection services.

sourceObjects_Location.name: United States
sourceObjects_Organization.name: United States of America, Government of
destinationObjects_GlobalCluster.name: Coordination and support services
destinationObjects_Organization.name: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
destinationObjects_Location.name: Niger
destinationObjects_Cluster.name: Coordination and Support Services
destinationObjects_Plan.name: Niger Plan de Réponse Humanitaire 2018
destinationObjects_Project.name: Strengthening humanitarian coordination, advocacy and quality of humanitarian assistance
reportDetails_organization: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
project_text: Strengthening humanitarian coordination, advocacy and quality of humanitarian assistance (i) expanding humanitarian access to deliver life-saving assistance and protection in Diffa, a complex operating environment where the security situation remains volatile; (ii) coordinate the provision of humanitarian assistance in other parts of the country during peaks of malnutrition, food insecurity, epidemics and  flooding; (iii) establishing an efficient humanitarian coordination mechanism in Diffa, (iv) optimizing the cooperation with the Government of Niger, capitalizing on their willingness to take the lead on humanitarian issues while considering how to further support them in terms of capacity building; (v) ensuring adequate funding for humanitarian activities in all humanitarian sectors, including by working closely with donors towards more support and funding tools to national  responders, and the scaling up of cash-based programming.
